实战教程：开发 CRUD 功能

Tagtag Starter frontend is developed based on Vue 3 + TypeScript + Vite, adopting component-based and modular design concepts. This document will detail the specifications, best practices, and common tools for frontend development, helping developers quickly get started and maintain code quality.
Build tool, providing fast development experience
UI component library, providing rich enterprise-level components
High-performance table component for complex table scenarios
The frontend project adopts a Monorepo structure, located in the
directory. This structure allows us to manage multiple applications and shared packages in one repository, improving code reusability and maintenance efficiency.

frontend/
├── apps/                  # Application directory
│   └── tagtag/            # Main application
│       ├── src/           # Source code
│       │   ├── adapter/   # Adapter layer, wrapping third-party libraries
│       │   │   ├── component/ # Component adapters
│       │   │   ├── form.ts    # Form adapter
│       │   │   └── vxe-table.ts # Table adapter
│       │   ├── api/       # API definitions
│       │   │   ├── core/  # Core APIs (login, user, menu, etc.)
│       │   │   ├── modules/ # Module APIs (iam, system, storage)
│       │   │   ├── request.ts # Request client configuration
│       │   │   └── index.ts
│       │   ├── assets/    # Static assets
│       │   ├── components/# Public components
│       │   ├── composables/# Composable functions
│       │   ├── hooks/     # Custom Hooks
│       │   │   └── web/   # Web related Hooks
│       │   ├── layouts/   # Layout components
│       │   │   ├── auth.vue    # Auth layout
│       │   │   └── basic.vue   # Basic layout
│       │   ├── locales/   # Internationalization
│       │   │   └── langs/ # Language packs
│       │   ├── router/    # Routing configuration
│       │   │   ├── routes/ # Route definitions
│       │   │   ├── guard.ts  # Route guards
│       │   │   └── access.ts # Permission control
│       │   ├── store/     # State management
│       │   │   ├── auth.ts    # Auth state
│       │   │   └── index.ts
│       │   ├── styles/    # Style files
│       │   ├── types/     # Type definitions
│       │   ├── utils/     # Utility functions
│       │   ├── views/     # Page components
│       │   │   ├── _core/ # Core pages (login, 404, etc.)
│       │   │   ├── dashboard/ # Dashboard
│       │   │   └── modules/ # Business modules
│       │   ├── app.vue    # Root component
│       │   ├── bootstrap.ts # App startup logic
│       │   ├── main.ts    # Entry file
│       │   └── preferences.ts # App preferences
│       ├── public/        # Public resources
│       ├── index.html     # HTML template
│       ├── vite.config.ts # Vite configuration
│       └── tsconfig.json  # TypeScript configuration
├── internal/              # Internal packages
│   ├── lint-configs/      # Code checking configuration
│   ├── node-utils/        # Node utility functions
│   ├── tailwind-config/   # Tailwind CSS configuration
│   ├── tsconfig/          # TypeScript configuration
│   └── vite-config/       # Vite configuration
├── packages/              # Public packages
│   └── @core/             # Core packages
│       ├── base/          # Base functionality (design, icons, shared utils)
│       ├── composables/   # Composable functions
│       └── typings/       # Type definitions
└── pnpm-workspace.yaml    # pnpm workspace configuration
: Adapter layer, used to wrap third-party libraries and reduce dependency on specific libraries. For example,
: API layer, divided into core APIs and module APIs. Core APIs contain basic interfaces like login, user info, menu, etc. Module APIs are divided by business modules.
: Routing configuration, containing route definitions, route guards, and permission control. Supports dynamic route generation, dynamically loading menus and routes based on user permissions.
: State management, using Pinia for global state management. Mainly contains auth state, user info, permissions, and other global states.
: Page components, organized by functional modules.
: Consistent with file name, use PascalCase naming

File name: UserFormDrawer.vue
Component name: UserFormDrawer
Usage: <user-form-drawer />
Components should follow the structure below:
language-vue shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

<template>
  <!-- Component template -->
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
// Component logic
</script>

<style scoped>
/* Component styles */
</style>
syntax sugar to simplify component development
Organize code in the following order:
: Pass data from ancestor to descendant components, suitable for deeply nested scenarios
: Global state management, suitable for cross-component shared state
attribute to ensure style scope isolation
Use CSS variables to manage theme colors and general styles
language-css shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
For reusable components, it is recommended to:
Add clear Props type definitions for components
Write component documentation and usage examples
File name should be consistent with Hook name, use camelCase naming
Hooks should return reactive data and methods for easy component use
Used to manage user authentication status, encapsulating login, logout, permission checking, and other functions.
language-typescript shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight
Used to simplify table component development, encapsulating pagination, search, reset, and other functions.
Used to load and manage dictionary data, supporting parallel loading of multiple dictionary types.

<template>
  <a-form-item label="Gender">
    <a-select v-model:value="form.gender">
      <a-select-option 
        v-for="item in genderDict" 
        :key="item.value" 
        :value="item.value"
      >
        {{ item.label }}
      </a-select-option>
    </a-select>
  </a-form-item>
</template>

<script setup lang="ts">
import { reactive } from 'vue';
import { useDict } from '@/hooks/useDict';

const { genderDict } = useDict('gender');

const form = reactive({
  gender: undefined
});
</script>
: Each Hook is responsible for only one function, keep it concise
: Design general Hooks, avoid business logic coupling
: Add complete TypeScript type definitions for Hooks
: Clean up side effects when components are unmounted, such as timers, event listeners, etc.
to return reactive data for easy destructuring
: Add appropriate error handling logic in Hooks
Pinia is the official recommended state management library for Vue 3, which is lighter and more concise than Vuex. In Tagtag Starter, we use Pinia for global state management.
: Each module corresponds to a Store file
: Use camelCase naming, async Actions should return Promise
In the Tagtag Starter project, the authentication Store implementation is more complete, including token refresh, login state management, and other functions.
: Divide Store by functional modules, avoid single Store being too large. For example:
: Only put globally shared state into Store, use
: All async operations should be placed in Actions, keeping state updates traceable
: For states that need persistence, use localStorage or cookie storage
: Avoid repeatedly calculating the same derived state in components
: Add complete TypeScript type definitions for State, Getters, and Actions
The frontend uses Axios for API requests, and the configuration is located in
Divide APIs by modules, each module corresponds to a file.
: Uniformly use async/await to handle async requests
: Add try/catch to handle errors when calling APIs
: Validate parameter legitimacy before calling APIs
: Display appropriate loading state to improve user experience
Routing configuration is located in the
Use route guards to implement permission control and page jump logic.
// Not logged in, redirect to login page
The frontend project uses ESLint for code checking, and the rules are configured in the
Use Prettier for code formatting, and the configuration is located in the
Use Commitizen to commit code, following the Angular commit specification:
Use Vitest for unit testing, and test files are located in the
Use Cypress for end-to-end testing, and test files are located in the
or dynamic import to lazy load components
: Use CDN to accelerate static resource access
language-bash shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme material-theme-palenight

# Install dependencies
pnpm install

# Start development server
pnpm dev

# Build production version
pnpm build

# Preview production version
pnpm preview

# Run ESLint
pnpm lint

# Run Prettier
pnpm format

# Run unit tests
pnpm test:unit

# Run E2E tests
pnpm test:e2e
: Use meaningful variable and function names
: Organize code structure reasonably, use blank lines to separate different logic blocks
: Write documentation for public components and functions
: Write test cases for core functionality
: Use Git reasonably, moderate commit granularity
: Appropriate animation effects to improve user experience
: Ensure smooth page loading and interaction

This document introduces the specifications, best practices, and common tools for Tagtag frontend development. Following these specifications can improve code quality, maintainability, and development efficiency, ensuring smooth team collaboration.

Frontend development is a continuously evolving field. Developers are advised to keep up with the latest developments in Vue 3, TypeScript, and other technologies, and continuously learn and practice new technologies and best practices.
